snippet: Tony Gwynn, who died of cancer, said proudly that he learned something new at the ballpark every day, a simple, powerful lesson in a sport with a punishing schedule.
abstract: Tyler Kepner On Baseball column; Tony Gwynn, who died of cancer at age 54, may have embodied baseball better than anyone else who has played it, because of the wonder he found in the game and joy he took in applying his daily discoveries; San Diego Padres 15-time All-Star and Hall of Famer had 3,141 career hits and .338 batting average.
lead_paragraph: Tony Gwynn, who died of cancer, said proudly that he learned something new at the ballpark every day, a simple, powerful lesson in a sport with a punishing schedule.

headline.seo: Tony Gwynn’s 2 Hitting Secrets: Work and More Work
headline.main: In a .338 Lifetime Average, Every Day Counted
